title.narrative: Improving the physical and psychological conditions of older Syrian and Lebanese women and men affected by chronic health conditions

description.narrative: A contribution to the reduction of morbidity rates of Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension and reduction in psychological distress of sufferers of these diseases has been made among older men and women from Syrian refugee and host communities. Syrian refugees have increased access to enhanced primary health care and Syrian refugees have access to enhanced systems for detection and prevention of diabetes and hypertension
Syrian refugees have access to enhanced systems for detection and prevention of diabetes and hypertension
Syrian refugees have increased access to enhanced primary health care

Taking on board the importance of having a holistic and community oriented approach to the prevention and management of NCDs conditions such as hypertension (HTN) and diabetes (T2D), as per national guidelines, this programme targets:  Primarily Syrian refugees with hypertension and/or T2D or at risk of developing these conditions, with particular attention to those affected by psychosocial distress  Host community members at risk of or already affected by the same conditions will also be targeted in line with Lebanese government policy and good humanitarian practice  Civil society organizations already running PHCs and MMUs such as AMEL International, the YMCA, Imam Sadr Foundation and Makassed as well as their medical and paramedical staffSyrian refugees community Lebanese host communities Others (Palestinian or Iraqi refugees amongst others) Civil society organizations At least 60% of beneficiaries 30% of beneficiaries Max 10% of beneficiaries 35 health staff (GPs, cardiologists, pharmacists, nurses) - 1,885 per month for NCDs related services - 1000 over 36 months for PSS services 5,400 men and women at risk of hypertension and type II diabetes 40 community workers

mailing-address.narrative: Tavis House, 1-6 Tavistock Square, London WC1H 9NA
